You are wrong about chemical reactions. They don't convert mass to energy, they release energy through bonds. The move from higher energy to lower energy bonds and release the energy stored in their bonds, that's an exothermic reaction. There are also chemical reactions called endothermic reactions, they do the opposite and actually take energy to occur. You DO NOT create or destroy matter in exothermic or endothermic chemical reactions.

In actual practice anti-matter reactions, at least in accelerators, are not 100% efficient. Not all the matter goes to photons. Some of it comes back as reconstituted matter in the form of scattering particles.

To be precise, black holes produce so much energy from stuff falling into them because those 42% are the mass equivalent of the kinetic energy gained by it which can be turned into radiation e.g. by fricton. None of the rest mass of the object is converted to energy, assuming it doesn't undergo nuclear reactions in the process (which would not add much to it anyway, as said in the video) or get into an environment that is extreme enough to violate particle conservation laws. Hawking radiation violates particle conservation, for example.

Another pretty efficient energy source involving black holes is to extract rotational energy from it. That can be achieved by sending stuff close to it, but not so close that it cannot escape anymore on its own, which can lead to that stuff ending up with a higher sum of kinetic plus potential energy than before... or perhaps it just works wirh photons which can end up witha higher frequency (aka more energy) than before, I'm not sure (there is a video about it somewhere on Youtube). That would be an almost limitless source of energy, as black holes can have stupendously huge amounts of it. For example, the supermassive black hole at M87 (the one we have a picture of) has a rotational energy of about the equivalent of 10 trillion supernova explosions IIRC... and a few people here might know about how huge just a single supernova is, from the following cite from what-if.xkcd.com/73/

"However big you think supernovae are, they're bigger than that.
Here's a question to give you a sense of scale: Which of the following would be brighter, in terms of the amount of energy delivered to your retina:
- A supernova, seen from as far away as the Sun is from the Earth, or
- The detonation of a hydrogen bomb pressed against your eyeball?
Applying the physicist rule of thumb suggests that the supernova is brighter. And indeed, it is ... by nine orders of magnitude."

Just a single supernova is so huge that some astronomers use a separate energy term for it: The foe. It stands for "ten to the *F*ifty-*O*ne *E*rg" which is the order of magnitude of a supernova, in cgs units which are still common in astronomy.

Aren't mass and energy essentially the same thing and aren't the forces involved all fundamentally the same too? In that case, everything is technically  all sides of the same coin, energy is kinetic, it is stored when it can't escape a force and moves when another force acts upon it causing it to be converted into a different state in the process when you lift an object up, you apply a force, giving it a potential moving energy into the system, when you release it, it falls back to it's base state and the energy moves again, when you apply heat to a material, it's particles store that energy and it is released as they bump into each other or radiate photons away transferring energy into different states or systems, in a chemical reaction, the particles store energy in their bonds and it is released when they fall into more favourable configurations or absorbed to force less favourable outcomes, in nuclear reactions it is the greater strength forces in the atoms nucleus that is overcome and  the energy stored in those bonds is released, in annihilation the fundamental particles have all (or close to all) of the energy they have stored in strong nuclear force released into a free state, the more force applied to the object the more of it's mass is forced to move apart, if the gravity is strong enough not only will the forces break the nuclear bonds apart but the force of any collision will cause the energy to become free and either reconfigure itself into it's most stable state until it is forced to change again, perhaps as it is absorbed into another mass, like the black hole. Arguably black holes should be near 100% efficient at freeing energy from it's current state but will capture any of that energy that moves into it's influence and convert it back into another state, but due to quantum effects, it will radiate all of it's stored energy away, either as photons, mass or some other exotic material over countless eons energy is the fluctuation of quantum particles and forces are interactions between that energy and at some level it is trying to find a state where  is uniform and flows from one place to another until it is in a totally balanced system where either it is so spread out interactions are no longer balanced or until everything is even such that all opposing interactions totally cancel out. I could be wrong but it's interesting to ponder what might actually be happening at levels too big or small for us to comprehend!

To be concise: Mass is never 'converted' into energy because the end products (even as radiation) have the same inertia and gravity as the original 'cat' (i.e. 5 kg). Measurable mass is constant and proportional to the (conserved) energy of the system with a factor of c^2.

Matter (i.e. cat-fermions) can be converted into excitations of other fields like light-photons or just fall apart with random heat motion that maybe more useful for Norway - but the total system always keeps that 5kg of mass resp. 5kg*c^2 of energy.

So about 3 kg will add to the black hole, the other 2kg (42%) will weigh down Norway until that energy dissipates away across it's borders.

Mass is not converted to energy in a chemical reaction. Burn coal, the coal is flown away in smoke. Not even 0.000000001% is lost. The coal just turns into smoke. rotating black holes would allow us to take advantage of super-radiant scattering. it works kind of like how an advanced swimmer may use a whirlpool to swim faster than otherwise possible.
To do it we would need to construct a spherical mirror capable of reflecting everything up to gamma rays around a spinning black hole just beyond it's gravity well (the ergosphere), then shine visible light in at an angle in the direction of the spin. some light will be lost to the black hole, most of it though will be flung out of the ergosphere with more energy than it had going in and will blue-shift until it eventually becomes x-ray and gamma radiation. Then you open holes in the mirror and let that radiation shine onto collectors to convert to electricity.

This doesn't seem right at all. Objects have potential energy the farther away they are from a gravitational field. That potential energy is lost when the object moves closer, which is how we justify the gains in kinetic energy (by losses in potential energy). When objects collide during falling into the gravitational well, this causes kinetic energy (taken from potential energy) to be converted into thermal energy via friction. Mass is not being converted into energy -- ENERGY is being converted into energy.

This story about black holes represents such a wide-spread misconception that non-physicists tend to have about "falling" - WOW! It's so primitive for being based strictly on our day-to-day "Earthy" observations (as opposite to space) I do not even know where to start! Let's say how much energy do you expect to get from planet Earth falling into the Sun? Lots and lots right? Wrong! Earth rotating around the Sun can be quite accurately viewed as Earth falling towards the Sun but continuously missing it because of its tangent speed component - so you get zero energy out! In fact the opposite is correct: you would have to expend an absolutely enormous amount of energy to make Earth to "fall" on the Sun (by stopping the rotation) and then having a very remote chance of gaining any energy back as Earth would simply accelerate towards Sun transferring its potential energy into kinetic energy with 100% efficiency (i.e. not releasing any energy but simply transforming one kind into another)! Also consider that in the view of E=MC2 and relativist theory in general that means that an object accelerating towards a black hole would be gaining the mass, as it grows with the speed, not losing it! Here you go: your logic is totally backwards from the very start! And I will not even bother to comment on that weird "friction while falling and thus heating and radiating" thing! Radiation does happen but it has everything to do with a gravitational gradient and an acceleration while nothing at all with heating by friction!

This seems a bit wrong to me. What's being converted into energy is NOT the object's rest mass (as it happens for the other examples - well, I mean, it's still potential energy stored either in electrostatic or strong nuclear fields), it's its gravitational potential energy, which becomes kinetic, which becomes then radiation (BTW good luck building that Dyson Sphere around the black hole to capture all the X-rays...). You can see it as mass turning into energy, but that's just because the mass of the object INCREASES due to relativity as it falls to the black hole.

Something that I actually wonder about is if the process of eating up matter and then evaporating for a black hole does not effectively correspond to full, 100% mass-to-energy conversion ratio. But then again, evaporating black holes radiate particles, so I guess no? Otherwise evaporation of mini-black holes in the early universe could explain the matter-antimatter asymmetry and clearly it can't be that easy.

Wait a minute... this principle relies on gravitational potential energy.
Isn't that just a principle used to teach people Newtonian physics? In other words, because of how gravity ACTUALLY works (spacetime curvature), isn't no kinetic energy actually transferred between two bodies gravitationally interacting? From my knowledge, gravitational potential energy doesn't ACTUALLY exist. It's just a mathematical value used to determine orbital trajectories, and to teach people Newtonian physics as apposed to general relativity, because Newtonian physics is easier to wrap your head around. That's why it's called RELATIVITY, because velocity is relative. Kinetic energy doesn't actually align with relative velocity.
Seriously, think about it. If gravitational potential energy was actually energy, since the effects of gravity travel at the speed of light, every object should collect energy from every other object within it's own observable universe, gaining more (yes, creating energy) as it's observable universe expands. Also, everytime an object fell towards a black hole, the energy it would lose would be gained back at a 1:1 ratio from the objects it was travelling away from.

Due to hawking radiation, black holes will eventually radiate all of their energy away over a very long period of time. Eventually they should convert all of their mass to energy, it would just take billions of years depending on its mass. As for the harvesting of the energy that it radiates away, I don't think that it would be feasible to create a power plant out of a black hole by dropping objects into it. Putting aside all of the gravitational problems that putting one in our solar system would cause, all of the light that was radiated away would be red shifted, changing the wavelength of the light and stretching the wavelength. Since the energy of light is directly proportional to its wavelength, the light emitted would lose a great amount of its energy to the black hole changing the 42% mass conversion into a much smaller number. The light would most likely be red shifted all the way down to radio waves which have much less energy than infrared light. although there are ways to harvest radio waves and convert them to energy, the structure that would need to be build around the black hole is just not feasible and would need an array of many satellites just to be able to harvest the energy back. Even then there is no guarantee that the satellites would be able to withstand the harsh gravitational tides that the black hole puts out since the orbital radius is so small. 42 percent of the mass would be converted to energy but virtually none of it would be acquirable. You would be better harvesting the hawking radiation which is almost nothing for larger black holes. Hopefully this post will save future cats from painful spaghettification at the event horizon.

The point of a chemical reaction wherein you harvest the energy is not usually to release energy from the mass of the reactants, it's to release energy by causing reactants to move from a higher energy state to a lower energy state. Saying that a chemical reaction has terrible efficiency is misleading - if you compare it against the metric of mass to energy conversion it may, but that's like saying that driving a car is an inefficient way to warm up the roads - yes there's a little bit of energy lost through friction that increases the temperature of the road surface, but it's not why you drove the car in the first place, and if you wanted to heat up the road there's a more efficient way to do it.

Hold up, isn't this actually converting gravitational potential energy to radiative heat energy, not the object's own mass? An object falling from a height is converting its gravitational potential energy into kinetic energy, which can then be imparted to other things to make things like sound and heat (and thereby blackbody radiation), but none of the mass of the falling object has to be lost for this to happen.

If you want to convert actual rest mass into energy with a black hole, drop the object across the event horizon and then collect the Hawking radiation that comes out. Burning it up in the accretion disk is no more mass-energy conversion than hydroelectric power is.

You can create a backyard blackhole with a strong enough set of lasers; this method creates what is called a "Kugelblitz." The mass of such a black hole is so low that shutting off the lasers would cause the black hole to evaporate via Hawking Radiation virtually instantly, making it relatively safe. Carefully throwing mass at this black hole would then give you the above mass to energy conversion efficiency.

I see this throw-away comment about antimatter's perfect efficiency in various contexts, and it bugs me. Sure, given two otherwise identical particle pairs of matter and anti-matter colliding sufficiently slowly may produce solely photons, and thus be maximally efficient at producing energy. But that is almost never the actual example used - as with the cats. If colliding individual particles, doing so slowly is never going to produce enough energy to run your spaceship/nation/etc; while colliding particles quickly produces non-photon particles whose total quantum numbers are zero. If you were colliding larger objects, such as cats, then the anti-particles coming into contact would tend to be the positrons and electrons, and the gamma rays they gave off would then either escape (yay, energy!) or, by interacting with the electric field of the nucleus, be converted back into a positron/electron pair and excess kinetic energy. At some point, you'd start to see nuclear interactions, where you'd have an anti-carbon nucleus interacting with a helium nucleus, or a hydrogen interacting with anti-oxygen. Wouldn't these imbalanced interactions produce more in the way of random particles, along the lines of the particle spew in an accelerator, than just pure energy?

After all, the effect of the gamma rays released by the first few perfect 'slow' collisions, the ones that don't escape fully, would be to increase the overall kinetic energy, i.e. the aggregate heat of the object, increasing the speed of the particles, and directly increasing the likelihood that subsequent collisions would reach the higher energy realm where non-photon particle production begins, and all the 'perfect efficiency' of your annihilation has flown out the window.

What would it take to actually achieve this perfect efficiency in a usable quantity in a controlled way? I think it would be a bit more than just accelerating a stream of electrons and positrons together, or deuterium and anti-deuterium, etc. And a lot more control than just throwing a cat and an anti-cat together.

The method in the video is not actually about converting mass, but gravitational potential energy. The rest mass (the amount of the cat) falling into the black hole does not change through the process. The higher potential energy at a far distance is converted to the kinetic energy as the cat approaches the event horizon. Then, the kinetic energy is converted to the radiation. No direct mass-energy conversion involved. It would be more accurate to say that once the cat is inside the black hole, it's mass is slowly being radiated through Hawking radiation. This is the actual conversion of the mass into the radiation.

If you have a small enough black hole, instead of a big one as you propose, the black hole will evaporate via hawking radiation and return close to 100% of the mass in them to begin with. The particle-antiparticle pairs appearing just above the event horizon would very quickly make the black hole very not black at all if you're using a fairly small one. Force a medium sized asteroid into about an attometer, and you've got yourself a black hole that'll die within about 2600 years, and radiates a good bit more energy than the sun does at a given moment. This seems better than trying to use an existing, large black hole, which can only get to 42% efficiency, while the entire mass energy of the black hole itself for a small black hole will eventually become available.

The first couple of minutes of this video are very good. I appreciate the good analogies which explain clearly how much of an object's mass is lost in a typical reaction. Unfortunately, the rest is almost completely wrong. This is because when an object falls into a black hole, the radiated energy comes from its gravitational potential energy, not from its mass. The mass doesn't change in such a process. The main mistake being made here is to ignore the black hole itself as a component in the reaction: there is indeed some conversion of "mass into energy", but it's not the mass of the cat, but the mass of the combined black hole and cat system. For a rotating black hole, you're actually extracting energy from the black hole's rotation (see: Penrose process).

I at first thought that this video would make the case that black holes convert mass to energy completely because they eventually evaporate if you wait a really long time. This would be a better case to make in this context, though you also have to take into account the thermodynamic efficiency in extracting such energy (Hawking radiation is thermal).

It's actually misleading to say that the reactants change mass after a chemical reaction.
The only mass that's lost is the mass of the energy of the connecting bonds.
The reactants themselves do no lose mass, so in essence you only convert energy into energy. If you want to count energy as mass, the energy released still has mass, so no mass is converted to anything. Energy remains energy and mass remains mass.

If E=m.g.h, surely a given mass's potential energy would tend to infinite and would in fact exceed infinite once it passes the event horizon? If theoretically I had a piece of rope (string rope) attached to the object with the other end attached to a generator, would this not be a very efficient way to generate power? Yes the rope would snap at some point, but it would continue to fall due to its momentum and the exponentially increasing attraction of the black hole. The question therefore is, what is the maximum energy you can get out of the rope (or chain- any strong linking device) per metre used and how efficient would it be compared to E=mc^2?

(Ps you could prevent the generator falling towards the black hole by placing it between two black holes, with rope going into each, tensioning it between the two.)

Pps. This requires a silly amount rope due to the distance involved so it clearly is just theoretical.

GW150914 (the first and largest detection of gravitational waves by the LIGO collaboration) had initial black holes of 36 and 29 solar masses. The final black hole was 62 solar masses (with some error bars). Three solar masses worth of energy was radiated in the form of gravitational waves.

@0:35 "If you collide a cat and anti-cat, 100% of the mass will be converted into energy."
This statement is technically not true. First off, it suggest that energy is an object which it is not. Energy is the potential to do work. This misnomer is common in sci-fi entertainment where you read statements like "energy beams", "heat vision", etc... There is no such thing as "energy beems", you can have photon beams, neutron beams, proton beams, positron beams, but no energy beams.
Second, and more importantly, anti-matter matter collision end product will still be anti-matter and matter. The total sum of the products masses might be less than the starting reactants where the excess momentum can be converted to produce work. Since you start with two masses and end up with two masses, you don't get 100% of the masses converted into energy. I am not aware of any massive matter anti-matter collisions that result into purely massless matter anti-matter products like photons.

there is an even more efficient way to convert mass to energy using black holes: Hawking radiation.

Hawking proved all black holes emit a tiny bit of radiation, giving away a bit of their mass until they completely evaporate. It turns out that this process is faster the smaller the black hole is.
